dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey B, so I was looking at this AAA study, right? Super interesting stuff about ride-hailing versus, you know, actually owning a car.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey B, so I was looking at this A A A study, right? Super interesting stuff about ride-hailing versus, you know, actually owning a car.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats according to a recent study conducted by the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety in Orlando, FL.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah? What'd they find? Like, is it actually cheaper to just use Uber and Lyft all the time now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah? What'd they find? Like, is it actually cheaper to just use Uber and Lyft all the time now?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, uh, not really, it seems. They tracked a bunch of ride-hailing trips, and get this: city dwellers who mostly use ride-hailing are shelling out, on average, over twenty thousand dollars a year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, uh, not really, it seems. They tracked a bunch of ride-hailing trips, and get this: city dwellers who mostly use ride-hailing are shelling out, on average, over twenty thousand dollars a year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Based on data culled from 243,838 economy-level, single rider trips taken in 20 U.S. urban areas, the AAA determined that city dwellers who depend on ride-hailing pay, on average, $20,118 annually

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Twenty grand? [interrupts] Whoa, wait, twenty thousand? That's... that's a lot! I mean, I thought it was supposed to be the budget option.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Twenty grand? Whoa, wait, twenty thousand? That's... that's a lot! I mean, I thought it was supposed to be the budget option.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, $20,118, to be exact. And that includes, you know, an occasional rental for longer trips. They're paying about thirteen bucks a trip for, like, six and a half miles.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, twenty thousand, one hundred eighteen dollars, to be exact. And that includes, you know, an occasional rental for longer trips. They're paying about thirteen bucks a trip for, like, six and a half miles.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the AAA determined that city dwellers who depend on ride-hailing pay, on average, $20,118 annually (including the occasional use of a rental car for longer excursions). The average user pays $13.15 per trip to travel a typical 6.66 miles.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, how does that stack up against actually owning a car then? Because I feel like owning a car is always so expensive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, how does that stack up against actually owning a car then? Because I feel like owning a car is always so expensive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's what you'd think, right? But the AAA says a new car, on average, only costs about $7,300 annually. And that's for driving, like, nearly 11,000 miles!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's what you'd think, right? But the A A A says a new car, on average, only costs about seven thousand, three hundred dollars annually. And that's for driving, like, nearly eleven thousand miles!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By comparison, the AAAs latest Your Driving Costs report estimates a new car costs an average of $7,321 annually, with 10,841 miles driven (which is the average among those living in urban areas).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so that's a huge difference! But, um, what about parking? That's always the killer in cities, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so that's a huge difference! But, um, what about parking? That's always the killer in cities, isn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It totally is. Parking can really skew the numbers. Phoenix, for example, is super cheap, only like $700 a year. But then you look at New York City...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It totally is. Parking can really skew the numbers. Phoenix, for example, is super cheap, only like seven hundred dollars a year. But then you look at New York City...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The cheapest big-city parking in the nation, according to AAA data, is in Phoenix, AZ, with an average annual cost of $708.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, don't even tell me. [interrupts] I bet it's insane.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, don't even tell me. I bet it's insane.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, over $8,000 a year just for parking in NYC! The national average is closer to twenty-seven hundred, though.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, over eight thousand dollars a year just for parking in N Y C! The national average is closer to twenty-seven hundred, though.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On the other hand, if you park a car in New York City, expect to pay a whopping average $8,088 for the privilege. The national rate is $2,728 per year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Still, even with high parking costs, it sounds like owning is still way cheaper, especially if you get free parking sometimes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, even with high parking costs, it sounds like owning is still way cheaper, especially if you get free parking sometimes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Like, if you have free parking, you're paying three times less than ride-hailers. Even owning a big pickup is cheaper than constant ride-hailing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Like, if you have free parking, you're paying three times less than ride-hailers. Even owning a big pickup is cheaper than constant ride-hailing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Needless to say, car owners who have access to free parking come out ahead big time on the deal, paying three times less than ride-hailers for their daily transportation. ... And even motorists who choose to test the parking gods by owning a big pickup truck in a big city will come out ahead over ride hailing at an annual average of $7,266 to travel the same distance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's wild. So, what cities are getting hit hardest by ride-hailing costs?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's wild. So, what cities are getting hit hardest by ride-hailing costs?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, Boston takes the cake. Nearly $28,000 a year there. Nashville, Seattle, Philly are up there too. Dallas, though, uh, seems to be the cheapest at around $17,000.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, Boston takes the cake. Nearly twenty eight thousand dollars a year there. Nashville, Seattle, Philly are up there too. Dallas, though, uh, seems to be the cheapest at around seventeen thousand dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For those keeping score, the AAA says those living in Boston, MA face the highest average ride-hailing costs in the nation at an annual $27,545. Nashville, TN comes in second at $26,397 a year, with Seattle WA at $23,951, and Philadelphia, PA at an average $23,201. Urbanites in Dallas, TX pay the least among the 20 busiest U.S. cities for ride-hailing at $16,944 per year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, overall, what's the takeaway from AAA? Is it just, like, don't use ride-hailing?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, overall, what's the takeaway from A A A? Is it just, like, don't use ride-hailing?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Not exactly. They say it's still a convenient option, especially for limited travel or if you can't drive. But for most urbanites, a personal car is still, you know, the more cost-effective choice. The car is still king, basically.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not exactly. They say it's still a convenient option, especially for limited travel or if you can't drive. But for most urbanites, a personal car is still, you know, the more cost-effective choice. The car is still king, basically.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whether you own a vehicle or not, ride-hailing services are a convenient transportation option... However, with the average American city-dweller driving nearly 11,000 miles per year, a personal vehicle is still the more cost-effective choice. ... For those who travel a very limited number of miles annually, or have mobility issues that prevent them from driving a personal vehicle, ride-hailing can be a viable and important option... But, for everyone else: the car is still king.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. Good to know. I guess it really makes you think twice about those daily Ubers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. Good to know. I guess it really makes you think twice about those daily Ubers.
